A.     Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Sweetwater Authority senior management is not only committed to offer a superior service, but to also maintain a safety and environmental program which promotes a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding community.  The Safety Coordinator administers the facility's safety and environmental policies.  The Safety Coordinator periodically evaluates the health and safety practices of facility employees to ensure compliance, and oversees implementation of the safety and environmental programs.  These programs include hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturer's documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan. 



B.     Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



The Sweetwater Authority facility uses a chlorine system to treat water.  Chlorine is used as a disinfectant to purify the water.  The chlorine is delivered to the facility in one ton containers, which are then connected to the water treatment system, as needed.  The liquid chlorine leaves the one ton containers and enters the evaporators, which turn the liquid chlorine into a gas.  The chlorine gas then proceeds to the chlorinators, where it is pulled into the injectors, which then sends the chlorine into the water distribution system.



In the Chlorine Storage Room at Sweetwater Authority there are two chlorine tanks connected to the chlorine system (only one is used at a time).  The controller in the Chlorine Storage Room monitors the weight of each one ton chlorine container.  When the tank in operation is close to empty, the controller shuts off the valve connected to that tank and opens the valve connected to the full tank.  The empty tank is then replaced with a full tank from the storage area.  This replacement is done by Sweetwater Authority operators using the monorail hoist.



The maximum total chlorine inventory i

s 32,000 pounds. 



In addition to chlorine, the Sweetwater Authority facility also uses aqueous ammonia, up to 29% weight minimum ammonia in the water treatment process.  The aqueous ammonia is stored in a 6,000-gallon storage tank, which is located within a containment berm.  Two feed pumps are used to draw aqueous ammonia from the Storage Tank, which is then transferred to the effluent for water treatment.



The maximum total inventory of up to 29% aqueous ammonia is 46,260 pounds (6,000 gallons). 



C.     Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Chlorine System



In order to operate the chlorine water treatment system, the facility complies with the following risk management regulations:



1) OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM);

2) EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) Level 3; and

3) OES California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program Level 3.



These regulations impose numerous requirements on the facility to ensure the safety of the public and on site workers.  The following summarizes the key compliance programs that have been implemented by Sweetwater Authority to prevent the accidental release of chlorine from the facility. The Operating Procedures program ensures that the chlorine system is operated in a safe manner.  The Training program ensures that personnel fully understand how to perform their jobs in a safe manner.  The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that the chlorine system is in proper working condition based upon routine testing, inspections, and maintenance according to manufacturer's specifications and industry standards.  The Management of Change program ensures that process modifications are implemented in a safe manner.  The Pre Startup Safety Review program ensures that adequate safety measures are in place before chlorine is first introduced into a new or modified process.  The Hot Work Permit program ensures that Sweetwater Authority's employees and contractors perform hot work

(e.g. welding) in a safe manner.  The Contractor Safety program ensures that contractors understand the hazards of chlorine and must take specified precautions to safely complete job requirements.



In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  This includes common practices outlined by the Chlorine Institute.  Chlorine gas detectors are located in the Chlorine Storage Room, the Chlorinator Room, the Chlorine Dioxide Room, Chlorine Dioxide Day Tank Area, and the lower staircase.  There are also smoke and heat detectors located throughout the facility.



Aqueous Ammonia System



The storage of aqueous ammonia at the Sweetwater Authority facility is governed by many safety features.  Much of the safety of the process is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the process.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program 1.  The aqueous ammonia system is checked by operators on a daily basis.



Sweetwater Authority maintains tight control of its aqueous ammonia system through various process controls and monitors.  In the event that the primary engineering or administration controls at the facility fail and result in a release of aqueous ammonia, there is a containment basin surrounding the aqueous ammonia tank that can hold more than 144% of the tank's liquid capacity.



D.     Five Year Accident History



The EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))."



Chlorine System



Based on the abov

e definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted at the time of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation on January 22, 2014, there have been no significant releases of chlorine that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 10 pounds of chlorine or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material in the last five years (January 2009 - January 2014). In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a chlorine release.  However, there was one incident that resulted in an internal incident investigation as follows:



A valve was stuck on the chlorine system and Sweetwater Authority called a chlorine contractor in order to isolate the line and replace the valve.  When the contractor disconnected the valve, a small amount of chlorine was released.  The contractor was wearing a cartridge respirator.  Employees of Sweetwater Authority are required to utilize supplied air when they are conducting heavy maintenance on the system.  Because of the incident, the facility is reevaluating the contractor safety program to include having contractors who are conducting heavy maintenance wear the same PPE that is required of Sweetwater Authority personnel.  

 

Aqueous Ammonia System



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted at the time of the onsite visit on January 22, 2014, there have been no significant releases of aqueous ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 1000 pounds of aqueous ammonia or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material in the last five years (January 2009 - January 2014). In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.



E.     Emergency Response Program



Chlorine System



Sweetwater Authority

has a Hazardous Materials Response Team that is trained to respond to chlorine emergencies.  All personnel at the facility are first responder operations level.  While a large majority of the employees are First Responder Technician Level trained.  Some personnel are at Incident Commander Level.  The operators and maintenance technicians are trained in the use of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) and chlorine repair kits (Type B Kit).  Annual refresher courses are held for the Sweetwater Authority operators, maintenance staff, and laboratory staff which deal with the procedures for handling hazardous materials.  During the suit-up drills, which are conducted annually, mock cylinders are used to simulate a release.  In addition, B Kits are used for practice on a quarterly basis.  The local police, fire, and hazardous materials agencies have been integrated into the facility response plan.



In the event of an emergency on the chlorine system, authorized staff will attempt to isolate the cause of the emergency by activating the Emergency Shutoff System first and notify management and the local authorities, as necessary.  The in-house HazMat Team will wear the proper safety equipment (a positive, pressure-demand, full-face piece, self contained, breathing apparatus or pressure demand supply air respirator with escape and a fully encapsulated, chemical resistant suit is required for response) prior to entering the emergency location.



In order to perform an emergency shutdown, an operator or authorized employee will activate the Emergency Shutoff System switch located outside of the Chlorine Storage Building.  The procedure is detailed in the Emergency Planning & Response section of Volume I of the PSM/RMP manual.  A chlorine specific alarm tone will sound over the Public Address system.  The alarm could mean there is a chlorine leak, but not necessarily.
